01.text: Start today with a peaceful mind, knowing the Divine is within all.
01.translation: Begin with peace, knowing the Self resides in every creature.

02.text: Your right is to perform your duty only, but never to the fruits of your work.
02.translation: You have the right to perform your duties, but you are not entitled to the fruits of your actions.

03.text: The wise see knowledge and action as one, for the true wise see sameness in both.
03.translation: The wise perceive knowledge and action as one and the same.

04.text: Work done as an offering to the Divine frees one from the bondage of karma.
04.translation: Actions performed as sacrifice liberate one from binding karma.

05.text: Meditation is the journey of the mind from distraction to one-pointed focus.
05.translation: Meditation is the journey of the mind to one-pointed focus.

06.text: Better is one's own duty though imperfectly performed than another's duty well performed.
06.translation: Better to do one's own duty imperfectly than to do another's duty perfectly.

07.text: Free from attachment and aversion, equiposed in success and failure, one is truly wise.
07.translation: Equipoise of mind in success and failure is called yoga.

08.text: The Supreme Soul dwells in every creature's heart, directing their movements.
08.translation: The Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, causing them to move as if mounted on a machine.

09.text: The Self is eternal, imperishable, and immutable; it cannot be destroyed with the body.
09.translation: The Self is eternal, imperishable, and immutable; the body is temporary.

10.text: He who sees the Supreme Lord prevailing equally in all beings, truly sees.
10.translation: He sees who sees the Supreme Lord present equally in all beings.

11.text: Offer your actions to Me, be devoted to Me, and you will be liberated from karma.
11.translation: Offer all your actions to Me, be devoted to Me, and you will be freed.

12.text: The wise man sees the same spirit in every creature, regardless of outward form.
12.translation: The wise see the same spirit in every being, whether in a Brahmin, a cow, or even an outcaste.

13.text: Better to die in one's own duty than to live by the duty of another.
13.translation: One's own duty, though defective, is better than another's duty well performed.

14.text: The Self is beyond the gunas, beyond the material world, and is the witness of all.
14.translation: The Supreme Self is beyond the gunas, the witness, the permitting agent.

15.text: He who has no attachment, whose mind is steady, performs actions without desire.
15.translation: He who has no attachment, whose mind is fixed, performs actions without desire.

16.text: Yoga is the journey of the mind to find the Supreme Divine, the source of all peace.
16.translation: Yoga is the separation from union with sorrow.

17.text: When the mind is restrained and the senses are withdrawn, one attains supreme peace.
17.translation: When the mind is stilled and the senses withdrawn, the yogi attains perfection.

18.text: The disciplined soul, resting in the Self, sees by the wisdom of the Self all things.
18.translation: Resting in the Self, the disciplined soul sees all beings in the Self.

19.text: Abandon all varieties of religion and just surrender unto Me, I will deliver you.
19.translation: Surrender unto Me alone with all your heart, and I shall deliver you from all sins.

20.text: The mind is difficult to control, but it can be restrained by practice and detachment.
20.translation: The mind is difficult to control, but it can be restrained by practice and detachment.

21.text: He who is equipoised in pleasure and pain, heat and cold, honor and dishonor, is established in yoga.
21.translation: He who is equipoised in pleasure and pain, heat and cold, honor and dishonor.

22.text: That supreme abode is attained by those who pass away without regret.
22.translation: That supreme abode is attained by those who pass away without regret.

23.text: He who sees the Lord Supreme abiding equally in all beings, attains the Supreme.
23.translation: He who sees the Lord Supreme abiding equally in all beings, attains the Supreme.

24.text: The wise perform all actions for the sake of yoga, abandoning attachment to results.
24.translation: The wise seek liberation through action, abandoning attachment to results.

25.text: Knowledge is better than practice, but meditation is better than knowledge, than follows action.
25.translation: Better indeed is knowledge than practice; better than knowledge is meditation.

26.text: The self-controlled man, dwelling in the Self, rejoice in the Self, and is satisfied.
26.translation: He who is self-controlled and satisfied in the Self alone rejoices forever.

27.text: Material nature consists of three gunas - sattva (purity), rajas (passion), and tamas.
27.translation: From the three gunas of nature spring all cosmic manifestations.

28.text: Know that which is beyond the gunas to be the eternal, immutable, and blissful Self.
28.translation: That which is beyond the three gunas is immortal, immutable, and blissful.

29.text: The body is called the field, and one who knows the body is called the knower of the field.
29.translation: This body is the field of activity for the soul, and the knower of the field is the wise one.

30.text: Whenever dharma declines and the purpose of life is forgotten, I manifest Myself.
30.translation: I manifest on earth whenever righteousness declines and the purpose of life is forgotten.

31.text: Those who seek freedom through renunciation are truly ascetics, not those without fire.
31.translation: True renunciation is freedom through renunciation, not living without fire or vows.

01.text: Arjuna, when a man dwells in the Self, seeing all beings in the Self and the Self.
01.translation: He sees who sees all beings in the Self and the Self in all beings.

02.text: The gunas binding the eternal soul to the body are sattva, rajas, and tamas.
02.translation: The three gunas bind the indestructible soul to the material body.

03.text: He who sees all beings with equal eyes, understanding their true nature, attains peace.
03.translation: The wise see equality in all beings, establishing themselves in the Divine.

04.text: Work done as an offering to the Divine frees one from the bondage of karma.
04.translation: Actions performed as sacrifice liberate one from binding karma.

05.text: The greatest discovery in life is understanding that you are not your thoughts, but the observer of them.
05.translation: Know thyself as the eternal witness, free from the fluctuations of the mind.

06.text: Every challenge you face is an opportunity to grow stronger, wiser, and more compassionate.
06.translation: In every obstacle lies the seed of an equal or greater opportunity for growth.

07.text: Your potential is limitless when you align your actions with your highest purpose and truth.
07.translation: When the mind is purified and the heart is aligned with truth, all goals become achievable.

08.text: Self-growth begins when you release the need to be perfect and embrace your authentic self.
08.translation: Freedom comes not from perfection, but from accepting yourself with compassion and wisdom.

09.text: The power within you is far greater than any circumstance surrounding you.
09.translation: Your inner strength transcends all external conditions; cultivate it through practice and faith.

10.text: Progress in self-growth requires consistency, patience, and unwavering commitment to your vision.
10.translation: Through disciplined practice and persistent effort, even the mightiest obstacles are overcome.

11.text: You grow most when you step beyond your comfort zone and embrace the unknown with courage.
11.translation: The brave heart that ventures into the unknown discovers treasures of wisdom and strength.

12.text: Self-awareness is the foundation of all transformation and sustainable personal growth.
12.translation: Know yourself fully, and all illusions that bind you will dissolve into clarity and freedom.

13.text: Your past does not define your future; your choices today shape the person you become tomorrow.
13.translation: You are not bound by yesterday; in this moment lies the power to create your destiny.

14.text: True growth comes from serving others and finding purpose beyond your personal desires.
14.translation: The highest achievement is to transcend the self and contribute to the greater good of all.

15.text: Master your mind, and you master your life; master your reactions, and you master your destiny.
15.translation: He who conquers his mind is greater than he who conquers a thousand enemies in battle.

16.text: Just as the body matures in childhood, youth, and old age, similarly the soul enters.
16.translation: The soul passes from childhood to youth to old age, and then enters another body.

17.text: The senses move among their objects, but he who controls them, fixed in the Self.
17.translation: The senses wander among objects, but he who controls them attains peace.

18.text: That which is present in the evening is gone by the morning, and vice versa.
18.translation: What is present in the evening vanishes by morning, and vice versa.

19.text: Those who are wise see with equal vision the learned and humble Brahmin, the cow.
19.translation: The wise see with equal vision the learned Brahmin, the cow, the elephant, the dog.

20.text: The wisdom of the disciplined soul is established in the Self when, having gained.
20.translation: The wisdom of the disciplined soul is established when he thinks 'I have gained nothing'.

21.text: One who performs actions without attachment, offering them to the Divine, is not affected.
21.translation: He who works without attachment, offering actions to the Divine, is not stained by sin.

22.text: The Supreme is the source of all knowledge, the goal of all knowledge.
22.translation: The Supreme is the source, the goal, and the destination of all knowledge.

23.text: He who sees action in inaction and inaction in action is wise among men.
23.translation: He who sees inaction in action and action in inaction is wise.

24.text: The work of a well-controlled soul, who is free from love and hate, is like water.
24.translation: The actions of a controlled soul, free from attachment, cling not like water on a lotus.

25.text: He who is satisfied with gain that comes of its own accord, who is free from dualities.
25.translation: Satisfied with gain that comes of its own accord, free from dualities, he is not deluded.

26.text: The wise man performs his duties with his senses, mind, and intellect, renouncing.
26.translation: The wise perform all duties with body, mind, intellect, and senses, renouncing attachment.

27.text: He who is established in the Self, whose mind is steady, whose senses are controlled.
27.translation: The steady-minded man, established in the Self, controls his senses and attains peace.

28.text: The happiness that is born of the contact of the senses with their objects is of rajas.
28.translation: Happiness born of sense contact is of the nature of rajas, having beginning and end.

01.text: He who is established in the Self, who finds joy in the Self, is illuminated.
01.translation: The wise find joy in the Self, illuminated by the light of knowledge.

02.text: Desire and anger, born of rajas, are all-devouring and all-sinful; know this.
02.translation: Desire and anger are all-devouring sinners, known enemies here.

03.text: The Self is beyond the gunas, beyond the material world, and is the witness.
03.translation: The Supreme Self is beyond the gunas, the witness, the permitting agent.

04.text: He who sees the Supreme Lord dwelling equally in all beings, the Imperishable.
04.translation: He who sees the Supreme Lord dwelling equally in all beings sees truly.

05.text: The wise man offers his actions into the fire of wisdom, thus freeing himself.
05.translation: The wise offer actions as sacrifices into the fire of wisdom.

06.text: One who is free from the notion of 'I' and 'mine', whose mind is steady, is dear.
06.translation: He who is free from ego, pride, and attachment, whose mind is steady, is dear to Me.

07.text: The Supreme Soul is the friend and witness, the permitter and the enjoyer.
07.translation: The Supreme Lord is the friend, witness, permitter, and enjoyer in all beings.

08.text: He who sees the Supreme Lord prevailing in all beings, undying amid the dying.
08.translation: He sees who sees the Supreme Lord present equally in all beings.

09.text: The wise perform all actions for the sake of yoga, abandoning attachment.
09.translation: The wise seek liberation through action, abandoning attachment to results.

10.text: O Arjuna, the path to yoga is through practice and dispassion.
10.translation: The path to yoga is through practice and detachment, not renunciation alone.

11.text: Better to die in one's own duty than to live by the duty of another.
11.translation: One's own duty, though defective, is better than another's duty well performed.

12.text: He who has no attachment, whose mind is steady, performs actions without attraction.
12.translation: He who has no attachment, whose mind is fixed, performs actions without desire.

13.text: Arjuna said: If you consider knowledge superior to action, why then do you engage me?
13.translation: If knowledge is superior to action, why do you engage me in this dreadful action?

14.text: The Supreme Lord said: I have said there are two paths in this world.
14.translation: There are two paths: the path of knowledge for the Sankhyas and the path of action.

15.text: No one can remain even for a moment without performing action.
15.translation: No one can remain inactive even for a moment; all are compelled by the gunas of nature.

16.text: He who restrains the senses of perception but still dwells on sense objects is a hypocrite.
16.translation: He who controls the senses of perception but dwells on sense objects is a deluded hypocrite.

17.text: Perform your duty, for action is better than inaction; even maintenance requires action.
17.translation: Action is better than inaction; even the maintenance of the body requires action.

18.text: Work done as an offering to the Divine frees one from the bondage of karma.
18.translation: Actions performed as sacrifice liberate one from binding karma.

19.text: The Self is beyond the gunas, beyond the material world, and is the witness.
19.translation: The Supreme Self is beyond the gunas, the witness, the permitting agent.

20.text: He who sees the Supreme Lord prevailing in all beings, undying amid the dying.
20.translation: He sees who sees the Supreme Lord present equally in all beings.

21.text: The wise perform all actions for the sake of yoga, abandoning attachment to results.
21.translation: The wise seek liberation through action, abandoning attachment to results.

22.text: Desire and anger, born of rajas, are all-devouring and all-sinful; know this.
22.translation: Desire and anger are all-devouring sinners, known enemies here.

23.text: The Supreme Lord said: The gunas of nature bind the eternal soul to the body.
23.translation: The three gunas bind the indestructible soul to the material body.

24.text: Free from attachment and aversion, equiposed in success and failure, one is truly wise.
24.translation: Equipoise of mind in success and failure is called yoga.

25.text: The wise man sees with equal vision the learned and humble Brahmin, the cow.
25.translation: The wise see with equal vision the learned Brahmin, the cow, the elephant, the dog.

26.text: He who is free from the notion of doership, though performing actions, remains unattached.
26.translation: He who has no attachment, whose mind is steady, performs actions without attraction.

27.text: The Self is eternal, imperishable, and immutable; it cannot be destroyed with the body.
27.translation: The Self is eternal, imperishable, and immutable; the body is temporary.

28.text: The Supreme Soul is situated in every creature's heart, directing their movements.
28.translation: The Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, causing them to move as if mounted on a machine.

29.text: Work done as an offering to the Divine frees one from the bondage of karma.
29.translation: Actions performed as sacrifice liberate one from binding karma.

30.translation: The Supreme Self is beyond the gunas, the witness, the permitting agent.

31.translation: He sees who sees the Supreme Lord present equally in all beings.

17.text: Start today with a peaceful mind, knowing the Divine is within all.

12.translation: He who is self-controlled and satisfied in the Self alone rejoices forever.

13.translation: From the three gunas of nature spring all cosmic manifestations.

14.text: Know that which is beyond the gunas to be the eternal, immutable, and blissful Self.

15.translation: This body is the field of activity for the soul, and the knower of the field is the wise one.

17.translation: True renunciation is freedom through renunciation, not living without fire or vows.

18.text: Arjuna, when a man dwells in the Self, seeing all beings in the Self and the Self.
18.translation: He sees who sees all beings in the Self and the Self in all beings.

19.text: The gunas binding the eternal soul to the body are sattva, rajas, and tamas.
19.translation: The three gunas bind the indestructible soul to the material body.

20.text: He who sees all beings with equal eyes, understanding their true nature, attains peace.
20.translation: The wise see equality in all beings, establishing themselves in the Divine.

21.text: Work done as an offering to the Divine frees one from the bondage of karma.
21.translation: Actions performed as sacrifice liberate one from binding karma.

22.text: The soul is never born nor does it ever die, nor is it that having once existed.
22.translation: The Self is never born nor does it ever die; it is unborn, eternal, and immutable.

23.text: As a person puts on new garments, giving up old ones, the soul accepts new bodies.
23.translation: As a person puts on new clothes, the soul puts on new bodies, casting off the old.

24.text: The weapon cannot cut the Self, the fire cannot burn Him, the water cannot wet Him.
24.translation: The Self cannot be cut by weapons, burned by fire, wetted by water, or dried by wind.

25.text: The Self is invisible, inconceivable, and unchangeable; knowing this, you should not grieve.
25.translation: The Self is invisible, inconceivable, and immutable; knowing this, you should not mourn.

26.text: It is better to die in one's own duty than to live by the duty of another.
26.translation: Better to die in one's own duty than to live by another's duty.

27.text: He who has abandoned all thought of results and whose mind is fixed in wisdom.
27.translation: He who has abandoned all thought of results and whose mind is fixed in wisdom.

28.text: The steady sage, whose mind is thus fixed in the Self, is said to be established.
28.translation: The steady sage whose mind is fixed in the Self is established in wisdom.

29.text: When a man dwells on the objects of the senses, attachment to them arises.
29.translation: Dwelling on sense objects creates attachment; from attachment arises desire.

30.text: From desire arises anger, from anger delusion, from delusion loss of memory.
30.translation: From desire comes anger, from anger delusion, from delusion loss of memory.

31.text: He who is free from attachment and aversion, who remains equipoised, is dear to Me.
31.translation: He who is free from attachment, fear, and anger is dear to Me.

01.text: The wise are grieving neither for the living nor for the dead; they see the eternal.
01.translation: The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead, for they see the eternal.

02.text: Just as the body matures in childhood, youth, and old age, similarly the soul enters.
02.translation: The soul passes from childhood to youth to old age, and then enters another body.

10.translation: The actions of a controlled soul, free from attachment, cling not like water on a lotus.

11.translation: Satisfied with gain that comes of its own accord, free from dualities, he is not deluded.

12.translation: The wise perform all duties with body, mind, intellect, and senses, renouncing attachment.

25.text: Better to die in one's own duty than to live by the duty of another.
25.translation: One's own duty, though defective, is better than another's duty well performed.

26.text: He who has no attachment, whose mind is steady, performs actions without attraction.
26.translation: He who has no attachment, whose mind is fixed, performs actions without desire.

27.text: Arjuna said: If you consider knowledge superior to action, why then do you engage me?
27.translation: If knowledge is superior to action, why do you engage me in this dreadful action?

28.text: The Supreme Lord said: I have said there are two paths in this world.
28.translation: There are two paths: the path of knowledge for the Sankhyas and the path of action.

29.text: No one can remain even for a moment without performing action.
29.translation: No one can remain inactive even for a moment; all are compelled by the gunas of nature.

30.text: He who restrains the senses of perception but still dwells on sense objects is a hypocrite.
30.translation: He who controls the senses of perception but dwells on sense objects is a deluded hypocrite.

01.translation: Action is better than inaction; even the maintenance of the body requires action.

02.text: Work done as an offering to the Divine frees one from the bondage of karma.

06.translation: Desire and anger are all-devouring sinners, known enemies here.

01.text: Start today with a peaceful mind, knowing the Divine is within all.
01.translation: Begin with peace, knowing the Self resides in every creature.

02.text: Your right is to perform your duty only, but never to the fruits of your work.
02.translation: You have the right to perform your duties, but you are not entitled to the fruits of your actions.

03.text: The wise see knowledge and action as one, for the true wise see sameness in both.
03.translation: The wise perceive knowledge and action as one and the same.

04.text: Work done as an offering to the Divine frees one from the bondage of karma.
04.translation: Actions performed as sacrifice liberate one from binding karma.

05.text: Meditation is the journey of the mind from distraction to one-pointed focus.
05.translation: Meditation is the journey of the mind to one-pointed focus.

10.translation: He sees who sees the Supreme Lord present equally in all beings.

11.text: Offer your actions to Me, be devoted to Me, and you will be liberated from karma.
11.translation: Offer all your actions to Me, be devoted to Me, and you will be freed.

12.text: The wise man sees the same spirit in every creature, regardless of outward form.
12.translation: The wise see the same spirit in every being, whether in a Brahmin, a cow, or even an outcaste.

13.text: Better to die in one's own duty than to live by the duty of another.
13.translation: One's own duty, though defective, is better than another's duty well performed.

14.text: The Self is beyond the gunas, beyond the material world, and is the witness of all.
14.translation: The Supreme Self is beyond the gunas, the witness, the permitting agent.

15.text: He who has no attachment, whose mind is steady, performs actions without desire.
15.translation: He who has no attachment, whose mind is fixed, performs actions without desire.

16.text: Yoga is the journey of the mind to find the Supreme Divine, the source of all peace.
16.translation: Yoga is the separation from union with sorrow.

17.text: When the mind is restrained and the senses are withdrawn, one attains supreme peace.
17.translation: When the mind is stilled and the senses withdrawn, the yogi attains perfection.

18.text: The disciplined soul, resting in the Self, sees by the wisdom of the Self all things.
18.translation: Resting in the Self, the disciplined soul sees all beings in the Self.

19.text: Abandon all varieties of religion and just surrender unto Me, I will deliver you.
19.translation: Surrender unto Me alone with all your heart, and I shall deliver you from all sins.

20.text: The mind is difficult to control, but it can be restrained by practice and detachment.
20.translation: The mind is difficult to control, but it can be restrained by practice and detachment.

21.text: He who is equipoised in pleasure and pain, heat and cold, honor and dishonor, is established in yoga.
21.translation: He who is equipoised in pleasure and pain, heat and cold, honor and dishonor.

22.text: That supreme abode is attained by those who pass away without regret.
22.translation: That supreme abode is attained by those who pass away without regret.

23.text: He who sees the Lord Supreme abiding equally in all beings, attains the Supreme.
23.translation: He who sees the Lord Supreme abiding equally in all beings, attains the Supreme.

24.text: The wise perform all actions for the sake of yoga, abandoning attachment to results.
24.translation: The wise seek liberation through action, abandoning attachment to results.

25.text: Knowledge is better than practice, but meditation is better than knowledge, than follows action.
25.translation: Better indeed is knowledge than practice; better than knowledge is meditation.

26.text: The self-controlled man, dwelling in the Self, rejoice in the Self, and is satisfied.
26.translation: He who is self-controlled and satisfied in the Self alone rejoices forever.

27.text: Material nature consists of three gunas - sattva (purity), rajas (passion), and tamas.
27.translation: From the three gunas of nature spring all cosmic manifestations.

28.text: Know that which is beyond the gunas to be the eternal, immutable, and blissful Self.
28.translation: That which is beyond the three gunas is immortal, immutable, and blissful.

29.text: The body is called the field, and one who knows the body is called the knower of the field.
29.translation: This body is the field of activity for the soul, and the knower of the field is the wise one.

30.text: Whenever dharma declines and the purpose of life is forgotten, I manifest Myself.
30.translation: I manifest on earth whenever righteousness declines and the purpose of life is forgotten.

31.text: Those who seek freedom through renunciation are truly ascetics, not those without fire.
31.translation: True renunciation is freedom through renunciation, not living without fire or vows.

01.text: Arjuna, when a man dwells in the Self, seeing all beings in the Self and the Self.
01.translation: He sees who sees all beings in the Self and the Self in all beings.

02.text: The gunas binding the eternal soul to the body are sattva, rajas, and tamas.
02.translation: The three gunas bind the indestructible soul to the material body.

03.text: He who sees all beings with equal eyes, understanding their true nature, attains peace.
03.translation: The wise see equality in all beings, establishing themselves in the Divine.

04.text: Work done as an offering to the Divine frees one from the bondage of karma.
04.translation: Actions performed as sacrifice liberate one from binding karma.

05.text: The soul is never born nor does it ever die, nor is it that having once existed.
05.translation: The Self is never born nor does it ever die; it is unborn, eternal, and immutable.

06.text: As a person puts on new garments, giving up old ones, the soul accepts new bodies.
06.translation: As a person puts on new clothes, the soul puts on new bodies, casting off the old.

07.text: The weapon cannot cut the Self, the fire cannot burn Him, the water cannot wet Him.
07.translation: The Self cannot be cut by weapons, burned by fire, wetted by water, or dried by wind.

08.text: The Self is invisible, inconceivable, and unchangeable; knowing this, you should not grieve.
08.translation: The Self is invisible, inconceivable, and immutable; knowing this, you should not mourn.

09.text: It is better to die in one's own duty than to live by the duty of another.
09.translation: Better to die in one's own duty than to live by another's duty.

10.text: He who has abandoned all thought of results and whose mind is fixed in wisdom.
10.translation: He who has abandoned all thought of results and whose mind is fixed in wisdom.

11.text: The steady sage, whose mind is thus fixed in the Self, is said to be established.
11.translation: The steady sage whose mind is fixed in the Self is established in wisdom.

12.text: When a man dwells on the objects of the senses, attachment to them arises.
12.translation: Dwelling on sense objects creates attachment; from attachment arises desire.

13.text: From desire arises anger, from anger delusion, from delusion loss of memory.
13.translation: From desire comes anger, from anger delusion, from delusion loss of memory.

14.text: He who is free from attachment and aversion, who remains equipoised, is dear to Me.
14.translation: He who is free from attachment, fear, and anger is dear to Me.

15.text: The wise are grieving neither for the living nor for the dead; they see the eternal.
15.translation: The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead, for they see the eternal.

16.text: Just as the body matures in childhood, youth, and old age, similarly the soul enters.
16.translation: The soul passes from childhood to youth to old age, and then enters another body.

17.text: The senses move among their objects, but he who controls them, fixed in the Self.
17.translation: The senses wander among objects, but he who controls them attains peace.

18.text: That which is present in the evening is gone by the morning, and vice versa.
18.translation: What is present in the evening vanishes by morning, and vice versa.

19.text: Those who are wise see with equal vision the learned and humble Brahmin, the cow.
19.translation: The wise see with equal vision the learned Brahmin, the cow, the elephant, the dog.

20.text: The wisdom of the disciplined soul is established in the Self when, having gained.
20.translation: The wisdom of the disciplined soul is established when he thinks 'I have gained nothing'.

21.text: One who performs actions without attachment, offering them to the Divine, is not affected.
21.translation: He who works without attachment, offering actions to the Divine, is not stained by sin.

22.text: The Supreme is the source of all knowledge, the goal of all knowledge.
22.translation: The Supreme is the source, the goal, and the destination of all knowledge.

23.text: He who sees action in inaction and inaction in action is wise among men.
23.translation: He who sees inaction in action and action in inaction is wise.

24.text: The work of a well-controlled soul, who is free from love and hate, is like water.
24.translation: The actions of a controlled soul, free from attachment, cling not like water on a lotus.

25.text: He who is satisfied with gain that comes of its own accord, who is free from dualities.
25.translation: Satisfied with gain that comes of its own accord, free from dualities, he is not deluded.

26.text: The wise man performs his duties with his senses, mind, and intellect, renouncing.
26.translation: The wise perform all duties with body, mind, intellect, and senses, renouncing attachment.

27.text: He who is established in the Self, whose mind is steady, whose senses are controlled.
27.translation: The steady-minded man, established in the Self, controls his senses and attains peace.

28.text: The happiness that is born of the contact of the senses with their objects is of rajas.
28.translation: Happiness born of sense contact is of the nature of rajas, having beginning and end.

29.text: He who is established in the Self, who finds joy in the Self, is illuminated.
29.translation: The wise find joy in the Self, illuminated by the light of knowledge.

30.text: Desire and anger, born of rajas, are all-devouring and all-sinful; know this.
30.translation: Desire and anger are all-devouring sinners, known enemies here.

16.text: Arjuna, when a man dwells in the Self, seeing all beings in the Self and the Self.
16.translation: He sees who sees all beings in the Self and the Self in all beings.

17.text: The gunas binding the eternal soul to the body are sattva, rajas, and tamas.
17.translation: The three gunas bind the indestructible soul to the material body.

18.text: He who sees all beings with equal eyes, understanding their true nature, attains peace.
18.translation: The wise see equality in all beings, establishing themselves in the Divine.

19.text: Work done as an offering to the Divine frees one from the bondage of karma.
19.translation: Actions performed as sacrifice liberate one from binding karma.

20.text: The soul is never born nor does it ever die, nor is it that having once existed.
20.translation: The Self is never born nor does it ever die; it is unborn, eternal, and immutable.

21.text: As a person puts on new garments, giving up old ones, the soul accepts new bodies.
21.translation: As a person puts on new clothes, the soul puts on new bodies, casting off the old.

22.text: The weapon cannot cut the Self, the fire cannot burn Him, the water cannot wet Him.
22.translation: The Self cannot be cut by weapons, burned by fire, wetted by water, or dried by wind.

23.text: The Self is invisible, inconceivable, and unchangeable; knowing this, you should not grieve.
23.translation: The Self is invisible, inconceivable, and immutable; knowing this, you should not mourn.

24.text: It is better to die in one's own duty than to live by the duty of another.
24.translation: Better to die in one's own duty than to live by another's duty.

25.text: He who has abandoned all thought of results and whose mind is fixed in wisdom.
25.translation: He who has abandoned all thought of results and whose mind is fixed in wisdom.

26.text: The steady sage, whose mind is thus fixed in the Self, is said to be established.
26.translation: The steady sage whose mind is fixed in the Self is established in wisdom.

27.text: When a man dwells on the objects of the senses, attachment to them arises.
27.translation: Dwelling on sense objects creates attachment; from attachment arises desire.

28.text: From desire arises anger, from anger delusion, from delusion loss of memory.
28.translation: From desire comes anger, from anger delusion, from delusion loss of memory.

29.text: He who is free from attachment and aversion, who remains equipoised, is dear to Me.
29.translation: He who is free from attachment, fear, and anger is dear to Me.

30.text: The wise are grieving neither for the living nor for the dead; they see the eternal.
30.translation: The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead, for they see the eternal.

31.text: Just as the body matures in childhood, youth, and old age, similarly the soul enters.
31.translation: The soul passes from childhood to youth to old age, and then enters another body.
